t: Job 21
Job’s Reply to Zophar
Then*p Job answered:
Pay*pn close attention to my words; let*ln this be the consolation you offer.
Bear*ln with me while I speak; then*ln after I have spoken, you may continue mocking.
As*pn for me, is my complaint against a human being? Then*ln why shouldn’t I be impatient?
Look*ln at me and shudder; put*ln your hand over your mouth.
When*ln I think about it, I am terrified and*ln my body trembles in horror.
Why*ln do the wicked continue to live, growing*ln old and becoming powerful?
Their*ln children are established while they are still alive, and*ln their descendants, before their eyes.
Their*ln homes are secure and free of fear; no*ln rod from God strikes them.
Their*ln bulls breed without fail; their*ln cows calve and do not miscarry.
They*ln let their little ones run around like lambs; their*ln children skip about,
singing*ln to the tambourine and lyre and*ln rejoicing at the sound of the flute.
They*ln spend their days in prosperity and*ln go down to Sheol in peace.
Yet*ln they say to God, “Leave us alone! We*ln don’t want to know your ways.
Who*ln is the Almighty, that we should serve him, and*ln what will we gain by pleading with him?”
But*ln their prosperity is not of their own doing. The*ln counsel of the wicked is far from me!
How*pn often is the lamp of the wicked put out? Does*ln disaster come on them? Does*ln he apportion destruction in his anger?
Are*ln they like straw before the wind, like*ln chaff a storm sweeps away?
God*ln reserves a person’s punishment for his children. Let*ln God repay the person himself, so that he may know it.
Let*ln his own eyes see his demise; let*ln him drink from the Almighty’s wrath!
For*ln what does he care about his family once he is dead, when*ln the number of his months has run out?
Can*pn anyone teach God knowledge, since*ln he judges the exalted ones?
One*ln person dies in excellent health, completely*ln secure and at ease.
His*ln body is well fed, and*ln his bones are full of marrow.
Yet*ln another person dies with a bitter soul, having*ln never tasted prosperity.
But*ln they both lie in the dust, and*ln worms cover them.
I*pn know your thoughts very well, the*ln schemes by which you would wrong me.
For*ln you say, “Where now is the nobleman’s house?” and*ln “Where are the tents the wicked lived in?”
Have*ln you never consulted those who travel the roads? Don’t*ln you accept their reports?
Indeed,*ln the evil person is spared from the day of disaster, rescued*ln from the day of wrath.
Who*ln would denounce his behavior to his face? Who*ln would repay him for what he has done?
He*ln is carried to the grave, and*ln someone keeps watch over his tomb.
The*ln dirt on his grave is sweet to him. Everyone*ln follows behind him, and*ln those who go before him are without number.
So*pn how can you offer me such futile comfort? Your*ln answers are deceptive.
